Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; poorly modelled back, with indication of clypeus, prothorax and elytra only; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside bearing crude hieroglyphic inscription arranged horizontally and composed of three signs; motif rather stamped than incised; longitudinally pierced; glaze thick, originally pale turquoise blue, now mainly yellowish white; pale yellow core.
Curator's comments: This scarab is likely a product from the Scarab Factory at Naukratis (on its various productions, see Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming). It could belong to Gorton type XXVIII B (Gorton 1996, 103-105). Though the hieroglyphic signs could have just some magical value, it seems more plausible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun. The nfr-sign has probably here the value 'j' by acrophony with the jb-heart sign (Drioton 1957, 13). Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 98)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.121) (phase 3)
Condition: Poor, chipped (broken off partially at perforation) and very worn
